thread.title: What investors can learn from the opposite sex

author: Kate Cowling
title: What investors can learn from the opposite sex
text:
What investors of both genders need to find is Goldilocks territory – a solution that's not too hot, not too cold, but just right. by Kate Cowling Men might be from Mars and women from Venus, but when it comes to investing it turns out both sexes could benefit from some interplanetary travel.
While men still outnumber women in the professional investment space and are not afraid of taking risks, women appear to have the edge with a couple of key traits linked to long-term outperformance, research shows.
To start with, psychologists have found women tend to trade less, something Vanguard's head of marketing Robin Bowerman describes as a "very good thing".
Men tend to turn over their portfolio up to one and a half times more than women, which drops their annual net returns to about 0.94 per cent less than their female counterparts, according to research in the Quarterly Journal of Economics that looked at the investing patterns of 35,000 households.
The behavioural bias is something that's also evident at an anecdotal level, as financial planner Claire Mackay, principal of Quantum Financial, explains.
"I have a large number of very senior professional women and they are on the ball when it comes to their finances, but they are not wanting to actively trade," she says. "Whereas a lot of my male clients do a lot of internet research, so I'll come to work on Monday and there will be emails from them asking me about what they've read or what they've heard at the barbecue."
As a general trend, Ms Mackay says her male clients have a tendency towards "thrill-seeking" and beating the market, while her female clients tend to ignore macroeconomic trends and come in with the question "what will this mean for my personal finances?"
Lured into investment Sally Herman, a member of investment house Evans and Partners' advisory board, has also witnessed the tendency in men to be lured into an investment by changes in a company's share price.
"[Women] want the research rather than trusting instinct or price," she says.
"When [my associates] ring their male clients and say, 'This stock's at a good price', the men will respond to that, whereas the women are more likely to say, 'Is it a good company?'"
Underpinning women's tendency to trade less are lower levels of confidence compared to men, who tend to be overconfident, the research shows.
"Women are more risk averse, possibly because [they are] more self-aware in terms of knowing what they don't know," Bowerman says.
But apprehension can manifest in a number of ways when it comes to markets and is not always a positive thing, particularly if it leads to unnecessary conservatism in women.
While it has been established that lower levels of confidence can be beneficial, by encouraging investors to think through their decisions rather than acting on a hot tip the pendulum can swing too far in the other direction.
Nasty habit Younger women (aged 35-49) who were affected by the global financial crisis have developed a nasty habit of shifting from equities to cash when there are signs of market volatility, says Belinda Allen, a senior analyst at Colonial First State Global Asset Management.
Ms Allen collaborated with the University of Western Australia to look at investment patterns in men and women among the asset manager's non-advised client base.
"Pre-GFC what we saw was that males and females generally invested together in an overall trend ... post GFC there's a big differential in how males are viewing the world and how females are viewing the world. Females have turned extremely risk averse and are performing much older than they actually are," she says.
"As soon as the sharemarket looks more volatile, they just switch out."
Young men have resumed pre-GFC investment patterns and still have a strong appetite for equities, which is suitable for their age bracket, the research shows.
Ms Allen says if a woman is approaching retirement, it makes sense to have a low appetite for growth stocks, but not if she's in her 30s and 40s. If the behavioural biases aren't corrected, it could leave women with low retirement balances, she says.
Less than men It's well noted that women retire on significantly less than men, with data from the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia showing the balances in women add up to just more than half that of men. Of course, it's not just investment philosophies to blame for the variance – broken super contributions from years out of the workforce, coupled with lower average incomes, play a huge role.
A woman's personal circumstance plays a role too, Ms Herman says.
"From a financial planning perspective there are different styles if a woman has been widowed and divorced ... In those situations they had quite often been in a partnership where the men had done the investing, so they were much more keen on a large cash holding. They didn't want to risk their liquidity."
Some say women could benefit from a more active approach to investing in their super, starting in their earlier years.
Simon Russell, director of Behavioural Finance Australia, says young women who lack confidence when it comes to investment might end up in default options, which aren't ideal for those with long investment horizons.
"If you are a younger female, you should be fairly aggressive in your investment strategy," he says.
Men, on the other hand, could learn from the more disciplined approach to investment that women have, particularly when it comes to confirming information, he says.
So how can women and men combine their best traits to become great investors?
Finding the middle ground So if men, in general, aren't afraid of risk but can be too overconfident, and women, in general, approach the market in a measured but sometimes too cautious way, there must be a happy medium.
What investors of both genders need to find, Ms Mackay says, is Goldilocks territory – a solution that's not too hot, not too cold, but just right.
"Overconfidence can be quite damaging, while a lack of confidence may mean you don't take sufficient risk to get you where you need to get to," she says.
Perhaps it can be achieved if investors cherry pick the best elements from both of the sexes and leave less desirable qualities at the door.
For men, that means harnessing the confidence to move through booms and busts, but drowning out the noise and impulse to act on water cooler advice.
It's fine to watch the market, Ms Mackay says, but don't respond to every price change or you could end up eating up your returns on fees.
"It's one thing to be aware of what the market is doing. It's another thing investing based solely on what the market is doing and how the press is reporting about the market," she says.
For women, it's a matter of continuing to think carefully about investment choices but not being frightened out of participation.
"It's never too little and never too soon. Keep putting money into investments, whether it's managed funds or direct," Ms Herman says.
And of course that's a lesson both genders can take on from the empirical research, she says.
"All of the analysis says it's about staying invested in the long term. Being invested and topping up the investments is the key."
WHAT WOMEN CAN LEARN FROM MEN · Back yourself – If you've done your due diligence, it could be a lack of confidence that's holding you back.
· Don't be put off by jargon – Women have a tendency to be put off by acronyms. Seek clarification if something doesn't make sense.
WHAT MEN CAN LEARN FROM WOMEN · Trade less frequently – Turning over stocks can be very costly in the long haul. Ask yourself, "Will this trade really help my long-term goals?"
· Check prices less often – If the aim is to build lasting wealth over a lifetime, checking your portfolio several times a day can be distracting. Try taking a break.
